title: Friday, 5th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

To Markets Live

PM

No let up, eh?

11:01 am
PM

Drowning in strategy and bank stuff this morning, post the BoE of course

PM

SO i thought it best if i just spend a couple of minutes throwing up grey that you can read at your leisure.

PM

Start with general strategy

11:02 am
PM

General message seems to be that it's a lot from Carney, but not enough nevertheless. We need Hammond to turn the taps on

PM

Sonali Punhani and Neville Hill -- Credit Suissue

PM

Bank of England: Necessary, not sufficient

11:02 am
PM

The Bank of England eased monetary policy materially today, with a broad
package of measures:
■ A 25bp rate cut, taking rates to +0.25%;
■ £70bn of asset purchases, comprising £60bn of government bonds and
£10bn of corporate bonds;
■ a low-rate funding scheme for banks (TFS)
The MPC also made clear that the effective lower bound for policy rates was
“close to but a little above zero,” suggesting that rates could be cut further in
coming months. We expect the MPC to deliver another rate cut of 20 bps to
+0.05% in November, when the full effects of Brexit are evident in the hard
data and the MPC's growth forecasts are disappointed.

PM

Our view is that these measures provide a slight economic stimulus and
materially underwrite financial stability in the face of the recent deterioration in
economic data since the EU referendum.
But we judge that the stimulus will be insufficient to offset the recessionary
headwinds. This is not a game-changer for the economy even if it is supportive
of UK financial asset prices (in local currency terms).
Easier fiscal policy would be more effective in stimulating UK domestic
demand, but such action only seems likely in the autumn. We’d note that the
Bank’s government bond purchases currently offset all the government’s net
issuance for this financial year, so today’s policy announcement certainly
generates capacity for fiscal policy to ease.
Consequently, we continue to expect UK economic weakness to persist in the
near term and the Bank to respond by lowering rates further, to +0.05% in
November.

PM

John Wraith and colleagues at UBS

11:03 am
PM

Bank of England eases with a vengeance

PM

25bp cut in Bank Rate and another £70bn of asset purchases
The MPC has acted decisively to counter what it perceives to be a very material drop in
domestic demand following the EU referendum. Bank Rate has been halved to 0.25%
and the Committee has voted to restart QE through the injection over six months of
£60bn of newly created reserves into the conventional Gilt market, and up to £10bn in
corporate bonds. We expect a further cut to 0.10% in Bank Rate in November.
In line with our forecast, more aggressive than the market expected
The MPC's actions were more emphatic than the market had been anticipating. Recent
sessions had seen a paring back of expectations reflected in a restrengthening of
sterling that partially reversed its precipitous post-referendum depreciation, and a
moderation of the extent to which the drop in Gilt yields had outpaced the fall in yields
on other advanced economy sovereign debt. Following today's announcements, the
trends of weaker sterling and outperforming Gilts have reasserted themselves and are
expected to continue to dominate.
Dramatic change to Bank of England growth and inflation forecasts
The August QIR was published alongside the MPC's decision and the minutes of its
meeting. There were very significant changes made to its forecasts for growth and
inflation, with the former cut sharply and the latter sent higher in the short term by the
steep fall in the currency, and staying above target even at the 2-3y horizon.

PM

Carney explains the Bank's response and makes clear it is willing to do more
At the press conference, the Governor explained why the Committee felt such a strong
response was justified. He warned there is a real possibility that the slowing of the
domestic private sector may prove even more pronounced than their new forecasts
predict. If so, further policy action will be swift and decisive, with the Committee of the
view that it is better to err on the side of doing more than necessary than to discover in
due course that the approach has been too tentative and exacerbated economic woes.
Fiscal policy changes later in the year may alter the monetary policy outlook
The Autumn Statement will be presented in November, and we await details of
expected changes to the fiscal stance before predicting whether additional QE may be
sanctioned in February 2017.
Implications for corporate bonds, equities and FX
We expect corporate bonds to remain well bid, with spread compression in the near
term also providing a potential boost to the primary pipeline. In equities, despite the
deceleration in UK growth we do not see a significant drag to the FTSE-100 given 75%
of revenues come from outside the UK. In FX, we feel comfortable with year-end
targets of 0.90 for EUR/GBP and 1.29 for GBP/USD. The path for sterling is also
dependent on political considerations, including the timing of the triggering of Article
50, and the evolution of economic data, but the balance of risks is for further
weakness.
Reiterating and updating our recommendations
Our recent forecast revisions and trade recommendations reflected our view that
today's outcome was likely. We reiterate that we anticipate further sterling weakness
over the rest of the year, and look for conventional Gilts in general, and longer-dated
issues in particular, to outperform index-linked and cross-market equivalents, and to
richen on asset swap on the impact of large-scale QE purchases.

11:04 am
PM

Then there's this corporate bond stuff

PM

Which is getting lots of people hot under the collar

PM

Here's Hans Lorenzen from Citi

11:05 am
PM

The programme
Against our base case, the MPC decided that the Bank of England will buy ‘up to £10bn of corporate bonds’ through a Corporate Bond Purchase Scheme (CBPS), and, depending on how you read the Governor’s letter to the Chancellor, potentially other private sector assets.
When?
The CBPS will start in mid-September.

PM

Why?
The decision to do so was taken by a margin of 8-1, compared to ‘only’ 6-3 for expanding gilt holdings. The Committee judged that corporate bond purchases provide more stimulus pound for pound than gilt purchases, as the investors who are crowded out will be more likely to re-invest in other corporate assets, and by lowering liquidity premia. The Committee also believes it will encourage issuance in sterling and, interestingly, that such purchases have ‘fewer implications for the financial system than additional gilt purchases’.

PM

The eligible universe
The BoE will buy £-denominated, non-financial IG rated corporate bonds of companies that ‘make a material contribution to the UK economy’. Bonds much have at least one IG rating, they will buy bonds with an outstanding in excess of £100mn, and they will only buy bonds that have been in the secondary market for a month or more. Unlike with the CSPP, insurance bonds will not be eligible, in our view. This definition is consistent with the BoE’s corporate bond buying programme from 2009. To our surprise, the MPC judges that the eligible universe will be about £150bn, consisting of about 150 issuers. Currently, the £ IG iBoxx index has only about £160bn outstanding of senior non-financial corporates. And updating the universe that was eligible for the 2009 programme, we had estimated that only about £55bn would be eligible. It remains unclear to us how the gap between the two amounts can be bridged, but it implies that their eligibility definitions differ from previously.

11:06 am
PM

How much should spreads tighten?
The knee-jerk reaction in bonds that we deem likely to be eligible has been a 10-15bp tightening. By comparison, € bonds that are eligible for the CSPP have tightened by 65bp since the ECB announced the programme on 10 March. We do not expect tightening in eligible £ IG bonds on a similar scale, because 1) the starting point for spreads is tighter, 2) the external backdrop is different, 3) the size of BoE buying may well end up smaller than the £10bn, 4) if the eligible universe is £150bn, then the proportion the BoE will buy is smaller than the ECB, which at the current run rate will hold more than 10% of eligible bonds by the end of the existing programme in March of next year. However, we still expect that the ultimate reaction will be considerably larger than the initial reaction and would target 25-30bp of tightening in eligible bonds from before the announcement. As such, at current spreads we would add in eligible bonds where possible.

PM

And then there's all the NIM stuff affecting the banks

PM

And this new TFS thingy

11:06 am
PM

Here's Fiona Simpson at Morgan Stanley

PM

We expect limited take up of the Term Funding Scheme (TFS) beyond
rolling Funding forLending Scheme (FLS) balances although the policy
does help highlight the Bank of England's concern on the health of banks and
ensuring transmission of monetary policy. Our back of theenvelope
calculations suggestan initial allowance of c.£70bn at 25bps cost implies c.
£500mn decreasein cost of funds for the UK banking system if it replaced
funding ata bank's averagecost of funds (according to the Bank of England
this is currently c.100bps).This in theory would go a long way to offsetting the
headwind from lower baserates on asset pricing with lower baserates
transmitting rapidly to the 4/5ths of £400bn of corporatelending and around
half of mortgagelending which is linked to floating rates.

PM

More helpful for challengers than incumbents? We believein practicethe
marginal cost of funds is already materially lower than 100bps for large banks
(for exampleinflows into currentaccounts havecloseto zero marginal cost,
corporate deposit costs arealready extremely low).What's more, for some
banks (notably RBS) loans outstrip deposits already, with deploying funds the
key challenge. In addition MREL/TLAC requirements imply banks will continue
to need to issue new wholesalefunding.For smaller banks however,easy
availability of long term low cost funding should help support propensity to
continueto grow balancesheets rapidly (and offseta headwind from the
phase out of theFunding for Lending scheme).

11:07 am
PM

Loan demand to us remains a key question and here weexpect fiscal
rather than monetary policy is likely to bethestronger driver.Wealso remain
cautious that competition may intensify in the mortgage marketas system
volumes slow, squeezing spreads further while morestringent credit standards
could also reducescopeto lend.

PM

Our estimates already incorporate lower margins and weaker activity -
we leave them unchanged for now with TFS offering some offset to
headwinds from a further move lower in base rates. Wecut our UK
domestic bank estimates 15%+ post theEU referendum voteincorporating
lower loan growth and moderating margin expectations (see UK & Irish Banks:
Brexit - cutting earnings & what's next? 29 Jun 2016).Wecontinueto seea
lower for longer baserate back drop as structurally negativefor UK banks,
particularly given headwinds to structural hedgeincomeand slower lending
growth.

PM

And some more from Citi

11:08 am
PM

BoE Cuts Rates By 25bps to 0.25%
As anticipated, the BoE has cut rates to 0.25%. Based on company disclosures we estimate every 25bps cut hits large-cap UK domestic bank earnings by an initial c2-3% and HSBC earnings by c1%. We have already factored this into our existing forecasts. Our 2H16 NIM forecasts are broadly consistent with both company guidance and consensus forecasts. Barclays has indicated it will re-price savings deposits to offset the impact of the rate cut, resulting in flat NIMs versus 2Q16, while Lloyds has reiterated the 2.70% guidance for FY16 versus 2.74% in 1H16. RBS is likely to update the market tomorr

PM

RBS has now reported of course

PM

2017-18 NIMs Likely To Miss Consensus
While the banks have discussed the 2H16 outlook, none of them have provided updated guidance on 2017-18 NIMs. We fear ongoing asset margin pressure via SVR churn and lower front-book pricing, as banks compete for ever smaller industry volumes (Halifax, the biggest participant in the market, has recently cut FTB mortgage rates), together with the roll-over of structural hedges will have a cumulative impact, depressing interest margins going forward. We model a sharp drop in NIMs in 2017-18 and are well below consensus.

11:08 am
PM

Fixed vs Variable Loans
The impact of lower rates depends upon a number of factors, the first of which is the asset mix. Banks with a large proportion of variable-rate loans are likely to see a bigger hit from lower rates. TSB (Sabadell) and Lloyds both have a large proportion of mortgages on SVR. Approximately £70bn of the Lloyds SVR book will automatically re-price downwards with any base rate cut.

PM

Thiknk that will do for now

PM

I'd offer to post a research pack in the usual place, but the bloody LR is broken angry smile

11:09 am
BE

(@jimpj: I bloody wish.)

undefined
PM

I think all that takes us directly into RBS

11:09 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 182.17, down 9.83 (-5.12%), High: 186.00, Low: 180.70, Volume: 11.90m
PM

Poor RBS

PM

It's just rubbish

11:10 am
PM

Relaunch is a bit of a flop

PM

No one likes 'em

BE

Yep. Numbers are pretty terrible for current as well as historic reasons.

11:10 am
PM

Even Ian Gordon, who is a buyer, has this aas his headline...

PM

RBS (Buy, TP 230p) Q2 2016 results: Worse and worse…

PM

Interims start here: http://www.investe...1608050700113368G/

11:11 am
BE

We know that RBS isn't really a bank, at least from an investment perspective. It's a fan chart of litigation exposure with a neverending restructuring programme on top.

BE

We can talk about when it might be fixed enough to pay a divi, when something might happen with Williams & Glyn, when the US stuff can be properly ringfenced, etc etc etc.

PM

Talk about it -- but rather short of answers

11:13 am
BE

Indeed. It's been eight years since the rescue and RBS remains ..... well, it's just a mess, isn't it?

BE

So today we get an outlook warning

BE

And capital is weaker than expectations

11:15 am
BE

If you dig down far enough you get a core that met consensus. But there's not much core and a lot of other stuff.

BE

Let me get Cazenove to summarise.

BE

RBS Q2'16 results show the continuing overhang of legacy issues with clean
PBT £0.9bn ex items 10% below company consensus £1bn and further
restructuring costs (£0.4bn) and conduct charges (£1.3bn) driving the group to
a net loss. CT1 and TNAV were below expectations at 14.5% (cons 15.1%)
and 345p (cons 349p). Management indicate that in the current low rate and
low growth environment, achieving the long term cost/income (50%) and
return targets (12%+) by 2019 is likely to be more challenging. On W&G,
discussions on a alternative transaction (to an IPO) are at a preliminary stage
and the group is not continuing with the process of creating a cloned banking
platform. In our view, this is likely to result in further disposal costs for the
group. We continue to take a cautious view on the outlook for profitability for
RBS and estimate a RoNAV of 5% in 2018/9, our 2018 EPS forecast is 15%
below consensus. Remain UW.

11:16 am
BE

 Q216 results summary: Clean PBT est. £0.9bn after adjusting for own
debt, disposals gains/ losses, IFRS volatility, FVA, FX gains in Central,
restructuring, litigation, VAT recovery and shipping. Relative to
expectations: i) Revenues of £3.1bn were 1% below cons, ii) Costs of
£2.1bn were inline, iii) Impairment of £148m (ex shipping) were higher
mainly due to a single name Oil & Gas provision in Q2.

BE

 Revenues/ NII trends: Clean revenues of £3.1bn are up +1% q/q after
making similar adjustments to Q1 and are broadly in line with JPMe but 1%
below cons. NII increased +1% q/q as -2% q/q decline in AIEAs was more
than offset by +6bps q/q increase in NIM which in our view is mainly
driven by the one off credit card release in UK PBB. Ex the release, NIM is
flat to down for each division except CIB. NII increased in UK PBB (partly
due to one off releases), whereas NII in other divisions was flat to down.

BE

 Balance sheet: Loan growth was strong in the quarter with UK PBB loans
growing by +3% q/q, Commercial loans growing by +3% q/q, Private
Banking loans growing by +2% q/q and International loans growing by +6%
q/q whereas Ulster loans declined by -2% q/q.

11:16 am
BE

 Capital and TNAV: CT1 ratio declined -10bps q/q to 14.5%, below cons
15.1% and JPMe 14.9%. The CT1 miss was largely driven by the £1.3bn
litigation/ redress charges taken in Q2 o.w. £450m related to PPI (new
consultation and other). TNAV/s of 345m was 1% below JPMe and cons.

BE

What's notable I guess is that RBS isn't really doing anything wrong here.

BE

operating profit missed by 11%, but it's all on one-offs that if you exclude you get a 3% beat thanks to costs coming out.

11:18 am
BE

(@alewis2005: nothing to do with me, chief. I'm keeping well out of this one.)

PM

Did Ross McEwan know what he was letting himself in for?

PM

somehow doubt it

11:18 am
PM

He's been there, what, three years?

BE

Since Hester exited, right? Which looks quite shrewd in retrospect.

BE

He chose a very good time to be pushed out, his reputation intact.

11:19 am
PM

Indeed

undefined
PM

So on Avanti quickly

11:20 am
PM

Cos it is being discussed

PM

Yes, we ran that piece at circa 11am yesterday -- price set off, as it was bound to

PM

But then it got alighted upon around lunchtime by the bullein t boarders, who immediately mis-read it

11:21 am
PM

Decided Avanti had rejected a 150p bid

PM

Which we did NOT say at all.

PM

Inmarsat tabled a indicative offer for the company and then, when the news of talks leaked, pulled out of discussions

11:22 am
PM

Why it has set off afresh for the moon this morning, i have no idea

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 45.00, up 12.5 (+38.46%), High: 53.75, Low: 32.25, Volume: 2.59m
PM

But look guys, be careful

11:23 am
PM

We don't know what Inmarsat's plan was, talking an offer so far above the market price?

PM

Was it just trying to get in the data room?

PM

Alternatively, are there competing offers well above the then market price? We just don't know

11:24 am
PM

All i would say is be mindful of MAST -- the Boston crew that hold a load of the Avanti bonds and also 10 epr cent of the equity

PM

They will be pivotal

PM

My guess: unless there's a bidder for the full busienss, they will continue to provide working capital for the foeseeable. Although obv Avanti need proper financing for the longer term.

11:25 am
BE

Note there's a line in the Telegraph about two other parties expressing an interest, post Inmarsat walking. Though I can't find it because the Telegraph's website no longer has a search function.

BE

No idea about that line. But as you say, there's a data room open so it'd be bizarre if Avanti's peers and competitors didn't take the opportunity to have a poke around.

PM

Well the line comes from me.

11:25 am
PM

It was at the bottom of the original story

BE

Oh! Was that downstory? I never read beyond the first par.

PM

Yeah well, I don't read everything you write either Bryce

11:00 am
PM

Welcome

BE

Just to state known facts though .............. Avanti needs cash. It needs a lot of cash to keep trading beyond Q2 2017. It's said that.

BE

Anyone buying now will have to be ready to fund a dirty great rights issue, which looks a reasonable possibility.

11:27 am
PM

Also note that it has a Panel exception thing where cos it is openly for sale, bidders don't have to reveal their identity

BE

But anyway, let's move on. Otherwise this'll all be posted on some bulletin board somewhere and we'll end up having to ignore unhinged emails all afternoon.

undefined
11:28 am
PM

teeth smile

PM

Footsie up a tad, btw

PM

After yesterday's big move

11:29 am
PM

All pretty mixed

BE

Yesterday mostly on sterling, I think, along with a bit of a relief rally for the non-domestic banks.

BE

If you put the FTSE in dollars (which I've been doing obsessively since the Brexit vote) it's barely moved for a month. Really. It's a period of unusual unvolatility.

11:31 am
BE

In terms of today's movers, though, we have Rolls.

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 743.00, down 14.5 (-1.91%), High: 753.50, Low: 740.50, Volume: 851.09k
BE

UBS saying you should take profit.

11:32 am
BE

Though because it's Rolls, with its rather complex accounting policies, the valuation work needs a wet towel on the forehead to get through.

BE

We see risks to aftermarket profit growth expectations in the context of widebody (w/b) overcapacity. After 22% outperformance vs. aerospace civil peers post the UK Leave Vote, we see little upside to Rolls Royce valuation and believe current valuation fully reflects the long-term cash improvement potential of the business. Additionally, our in depth analysis of the installed engine fleet drives our forecast of a mid-single digit growth in w/b aftermarket, below high-single digit expectations of the market. If our view materializes we believe this would lead to downward pressure on investor sentiment. We estimate IFRS 15 introduction to bring a £250m-£275m headwind to 2017e/2018e EBIT (no cash impact), making the stock look optically more expensive on profit multiples.

BE

So, in terms of demand it's all about widebody overcapacity. Too many parked jets using Trent 500s.

11:34 am
BE

Which is something we've been talking about for some time, I think. Such as here: https://next.ft.co...-a8ef-ea66e967dd44

BE

We examine in depth the widebody aftermarket growth prospects platform by platform and expect w/b overcapacity to represent a headwind to aftermarket revenue growth while we expect mix to place slight pressure on margins on the short-term before starting to contribute positively. We model ~5% CAGR in w/b aftermarket gross profit going forward – which we believe is below market high single digit expectations.

BE

.......... and ..............

11:35 am
BE

We examine the ratios used by credit rating agencies in establishing ratings and conclude that there is limited headroom above the downgrade threshold. While we do not expect a downgrade in our base case, we believe any event leading to further significant weakening of the FCF generation in 2016/2017 (e.g. downturn in passenger traffic, investment in new engine platform) could lead to credit downgrade risk. This may mean the company begins to explore options to strengthen its financial position.

BE

A £250m deterioration p.a. of FCF between 2016 and 2018 would trigger the downgrade, UBS reckons.

PM

hmm

11:36 am
BE

Which is quite tight.

PM

We're talking a possible right issue then?

BE

Well, steady on. If there was a serious risk one assumes that Warren East, being a good CEO by most measures, would've identified the problem and pulled a cash call with the initial kitchen sink.

11:38 am
PM

maybe

PM

maybe not

BE

Still, there's not much room here, particularly as Rolls isn't entirely in charge of its own fate.

11:39 am
BE

One more bit of UBS.

BE

Boeing is currently assessing the possibility to launch a middle market aircraft (a/c), while Airbus is analyzing the possibility to launch a stretched version of the A350. A new engine for the A380neo is also considered, although recent news flow seems to suggest a decision was moved more to the right. We estimate that the costs associated with the development of a new engine are ~£1bn while the costs of tweaking a current engine are £300m-400m. These costs are likely to be spread over a period of three to four years.

We stress test Fitch's financial ratios and conclude that an additional £100m cash consumption per year would not materially deteriorate RR's financial ratios. A similar exercise for an additional £250m per annum of investment would have a more significant impact, having the potential to trigger a credit downgrade in our opinion

BE

While we do not expect in our base case a credit downgrade, we believe any event leading to further significant weakening of the FCF generation in 2016e-2018e (e.g. downturn in passenger traffic, investment in new engine platform) could lead to credit downgrade risk. This may mean the company would begin to explore options to strengthen its financial position: asset disposals or a capital increase being some of the possibilities. We illustrate in Figure 15 and Figure 16 the positive impact a potential equity rights issue scenario could have on the financial ratios linked to gross/net financial debt.

11:39 am
BE

BE

Can't imagine how easy it would be to call a £1bn cash call on the back of half a dozen profit warnings, for a company whose financing structure is rather tricky to understand.

undefined
11:41 am
PM

Jsut quickly...

PM

https://twitter.com/faisalislam/status/761506581272006656

PM

Wonder what PGs got to say about that?

11:42 am
undefined
PM

What else do we have

BE

Not a lot really. We can go through results but they're all quite dull.

11:44 am
BE

William Hill prints a decent quarter (or at least doesn't warn again), though no-one cares because of this weird consortium bid in the works.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 310.50, down 2.8 (-0.89%), High: 316.50, Low: 305.20, Volume: 1.25m
BE

Which broke when we were on holiday, in the Sunday Times.

11:46 am
BE

Let's get to the results first.

BE

Via Deutsche.

BE

William Hill’s interims are in strong contrast with those of Ladbrokes (HOLD,
144.30p) yesterday, and underscore the progress being made at the latter.
William Hill’s guidance for the full year is maintained, although this perhaps
implies some underlying weakness given the strong Euro Championship. No
mention was made of any discussions with 888/Rank (NR): we see any possible
deal as potentially complicated, with few obvious attractions to William Hill
shareholders. We continue to view William Hill’s valuation as attractive (FY17E
PE of 10.9x, FCF yield of 8.8%), and the issues at Online as solvable.

11:47 am
BE

William Hill is reiterating its FY EBIT guidance of £260-280m against DBe
£285m and consensus estimates of £265m, which at first glance suggests
1H16 results look in line. However on digging into the H1 detail, it is clear that
the Euro Championship was a significant contributor and therefore on an
underlying basis we believe performance is possibly slightly weaker than the
initial read.
In UK Retail, EBIT of £94.4m in the first half looks strong, however this is
driven by a gross win margin of 19% materially above the "normal" level of 17-
18%. The company attributes the margin benefit to strong Tier 3 horseracing
and football (EUROs and second half of the EPL). We think it is reasonable to
expect this to normalize, and note that next year there is no equivalent sporting
event in the same period. Hence, in our view, the H1 numbers are almost
certainly slightly flattered and should not be considered underlying. Indeed an
interesting point is that Retail OTC net revenue growth at 2% is a little
lacklustre.

BE

We already know that the main source of the lower 1H EBIT yoy is Online, with
sportsbook net revenue down 1% and gaming net revenue -6%. The Online
turnaround plan is however ‘showing early progress’ according to the
company, with improved user experience and new product roll-out. While we
think it may take some time to deliver a turnaround at Online, management
seems clear in its strategy. Acquisitions in 1H16 have soaked up c£100m of
cash, with a further £60m absorbed by the share buyback (now suspended due
to merger talks), with net debt /EBITDA now at 1.7x.
Management has announced – but not quantified – a new cost savings
programme which will probably be discussed at the analyst meeting at 0900
UKT. We suspect other questions will search for insight into the potential
Rank/888 (NR) deal, as management has issued no comments on this in the
results statement. In terms of forecasts, we see limited movement today in
headline consensus numbers.

BE

So, yep, much as the warning said with not a lot of incremental new news.

11:48 am
BE

And we wait, I guess, for any kind of meaningful detail on the Rank, 888 proposal.

BE

Which has been totally lacking so far.

BE

PUSU is August 21st.

11:50 am
BE

For what looks a very, very, very complex deal to put together. A few figures via Goodbody.

BE

Here's where it starts:

BE

 Share prices as at the close on July 25 are used.
 Starting net debts of £42m at Rank, £593m at William Hill and -£136m (net cash) at 888 are
used.
 Cost synergies of £105m are assumed, implying 25% of the overlapping cost base.
 Deal and restructuring costs of £225m are assumed.
 A maximum net debt/EBITDA for the combined group of 3x is assumed. We choose 3x net
debt/EBITDA as we believe investors would not want the group leveraging up above this level.
Any implied increase over this level to fund a cash element of any transaction would require an
equity raise. In terms of EBITDA we use the pre synergy EBITDA as we believe this is the likely
to be relevant for raising debt.

11:50 am
BE

So .....

BE

In the first scenario, which we believe is unlikely, we assume that a three way merger takes place at nil premium for all three companies. Under this scenario, net debt/EBITDA remains at just 1.2x, well below our 3x comfort level. William Hill would have 62% of the equity in the newco, with Rank at 20% and 888 at 18%.

BE

... Or ...........

11:51 am
BE

In the second scenario, we again assume a nil premium for 888 and Rank, but assume William Hill shareholders get a 380p per share offer (15% premium), with 50% in cash. This cash element would equate to £1.65bn. With the existing debt, along with deal/restructuring costs, to fund this entirely from debt would imply total debt in the newco of £2.4bn (4.5x net debt/EBITDA). Given our assumption of 3x comfort level, we believe a £780m equity raise would be needed under this scenario. In this case, William Hill shareholders would own 40% of the newco, with Rank at 22%, 888 at 20% and new equity

BE

.... Or maybe ......

In the third scenario, we again assume a nil premium for 888 and Rank, but assume William Hill
shareholders get a 400p per share offer, with 50% in cash. Under this scenario, the cash element would
equate to £1.7bn, or £2.5bn total newco net debt if all debt funded (4.2x net debt/EBITDA). Again using the 3x target leverage ratio, this would imply the need for a £709m equity raise. Again we assume the equity raise is completed at par, which again some will view as unlikely.

PM

· UTC (referred to as 'Strategic Bidder A') put forward an all cash offer of $101 per share last July. They conducted due diligence and exchanged a draft merger agreement, but at the start of October they pulled out, citing ‘additional unanticipated costs to achieve synergies and concerns about strategic fit with portions of the Nortek business’, which lead Nortek to announce on October 8 that they were no longer in discussions.
· While they were in discussions with UTC, Nortek also engaged with two other strategic bidders (Strategic B and Strategic C) and 4 financial bidders (Financial A, B, C and D) and provided access to information and the data room. While negotiations with Strategic B seems to have gone nowhere, discussions with Strategic C seem to have been more meaningful, but ultimately they pulled out of an offer for the whole at the same time as UTC, but indicated they remained interested in parts of Nortek. Of the financial bidders, only one Financial C submitted an offer at $70-$70 per share but this wasn’t pursued.
· UTC came back in December last year to propose an acquisition of parts of Nortek and this lead to serious discussions in January of this year. However, by late January the Nortek board decided that it wouldn’t pursue this.
· Interestingly, on 1 June, Nortek got back in touch with UTC to determine if it was interested in buying the whole of Nortek, or if it was still only interested in parts of Nortek. UTC’s response was that they were not interested in the whole – just the CAS and residential HVAC businesses.
· While Nortek were concluding their deal with Melrose during June, they were also speaking with other bidders to determine if there was a superior offer available:
o On 12 June Michael Clarke – Nortek CEO – informed the Nortek board that he had spoken to Financial A and Financial C from last year’s sale process and they were apparently still interested in a transaction. The Nortek board granted them access to the data room to conduct due diligence, but a week later (22 June) both bidders said they were not interested.
o On 14 June Ares (the debt fund that is a major shareholder) received an unsolicited call from another financial bidder – Financial E – and the Nortek board then granted them access to the data room for due diligence. They ultimately put forward an offer of $70-$75 per share on 25 June (this is presumably the level at which a leveraged deal stacks up), but were told that it needed to be in the “80s” to be competitive. They don’t seem to have responded to this message.
o On 30 June Nortek contacted Strategic C to determine if they were interested in a transaction, but were told they weren’t. There was also a Chinese financial bidder, but they weren’t seen as credible.
· Finally, last Friday (1 July), Nortek again contact UTC to determine if they were interested in doing a deal. UTC told them on Monday that they were still only interested in select businesses, not the whole.
